title: Ruby Wax webchat â as it happened | Stage | The Guardian
summary: that 's it ! thank you for all your questions .
`` depression is a disease , it is n't a mood . ''
`` mel and sue should get another series , because they are the funniest women on tv . ''
`` i have no role models . and if i did , i 'd probably figure out their flaw. ``
`` mental health is physical health - it 's your brain , which is just like any other organ ''
`` living a career in sucking the life out of celebrities was n't in the end good for my health , but it was fun ''
`` tell shrinks what 's in your mind , do n't pretend to be ok. get your money 's worth ! ''

documents.title: that 's it ! thank you for all your questions
text: guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 1:08pm thanks for writing - i hope we can do this again .
but maybe next time face to face !
which you can if you come to my show sane new world which kicks off on friday .
google it for dates , and buy my book .
sorry to be pushy but somebody has to be !

id808463 writes : mindfulness , like many well-being therapies , support models and recovery techniques has its place and personally i use it , as and when i need it - just as i do with yoga , rambling , meditation and peer support .
not all on the same day and not all in the same way because every day i feel different from the day before , which means my support/needs will be different .
this is n't ground-breaking news is it ?

why then , when such a frightening percentage of our nation visit their gp with a range of limited symptoms ' linked to mental ill health , caused by such varying and diverse reasons ( or none , as the case may be ) , do they stumble out of the surgery clutching a pale green slip ; the contents of which , will have the same effect on those people day after day after day ?
so many of us appear to get it now ' and understand the endless possibilities for self-management , from comedy to candle making ( ? ) .
no one size fits all and better mental health can be and is achieved more and more when we actively mix up the medical model with the therapeutic model .
i get it !
i 'm doing it .
when will the rest of those who sign the green slips , sign up to a bigger and healthier guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 1:06pm if medication was the answer , no one would have a relapse .
but sadly , many of us have visited these terrifying terrains many times .
so the only thing to do is keep taking the meds if you really have the real thing , but also find as you suggested anything that makes you more resilient , to be able to take on the next assault .
and be prepared .
0114 asks : you 're still looking great , what 's your secret ? !
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 1:02pm la prarie moisturiser .
that 's it i guess .
alans512 asks : i practice hooponopono , which teaches you how not to think .
it really works guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 1:01pm so do i !
small world .
spillit asks : what is your view on antidepressants and the side effects when you withdraw ?
and do n't you think they are vastly over prescribed ?

i do n't mean for people who are clearly clinically depressed , even mindfulness ca n't really effect that , but i see people who are just tired or low being put on effexor and a voice in mind head ( not an audible one : ) is saying you will be on that for years because the physical side effects of stopping it will be too hideous .
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 1:00pm i think gps should be arrested for prescribing antidepressants for people having a bad hair day .
or just low .
i hate that word .
i do n't know about any side effects - i 'm sure there are but that 's no reason not to take antidepressants , if you have a real disease .
it 's far worse to have the disease - screw the side effects .
andrew adam asks : how would you deal with the never-ending array of beige paints were you faced with them now ?
[ read your first book x ] guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:58pm i have been , and i now call in an expert .
my advice is always use elephant breath on everything .

jon chanter writes : hi ruby , psychiatry-uk.com is the only online psychiatric consultation service in the uk - we are cqc registered - so qualified to provide services into the nhs - and can undercut the cost of a consultation with a psychiatrist by about 50 % .
what is more , we can get someone in front of a specialist within a couple of days and from the privacy of their own home but no-one in the nhs is interested !
any suggestions ?
any contacts ?

i must admit that it is very depressing knowing that we have an answer to a lot of people 's problems - but no support and help in getting it made available guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:56pm just advertise online , and they will come .
i 'd say you 're giving people a good deal if you are what you say .
lyingscameron asks : how do you manage your anxiety when you are trapped in a situation that you ca n't get out of e.g .
when you have to perform in some way in public ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:54pm pretend to faint .
nobody will ever think you 're faking it .
id3905564 asks : how do you think you could help men who have problems with anxiety/depression and modern life talk to their friends about it .
i 've recently had cancer , and was diagnosed clear 18 months ago .
i went through the operation and treatment fine - no probs mate .

since then i 've had like ptsd where i feel worse than i did when i was going through it , its hard to talk to people about feeling like you have n't done enough and you have n't the things you are supposed to have and you feel a pressure to live like no one else .
but it 's hard to talk to your mates about this .
men still have problems dealing with emotional issues in society .
do you have any ideas to remedy this ?
a pint in the pub does n't always help .

guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:53pm the fact that you are so articulate and evolved to be able to describe exactly what you 're going through without being self-indulgent , is such a sign that men are now able to talk about the real stuff of life .
i find men talk about this stuff talk to be more about this stuff than women .
if you could find a walk-in centre - and i know there are some , but you 'll have to hunt for them , so you can meet your people - i 'd walk in there as fast as i can .
there you 'll meet people just like you who speak your language .
hongkongblue asks : ruby - what 's your favourite cheese ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:48pm what the cheese called when you make it in your body ?
toe cheese ?
weathermum asks : ruby , when you 're really down , what do you think about and what do you do to keep yourself going ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:47pm i think about how my life has been a failure , and that i have gotten away with everything because underneath i am nothing .
that 's normally what i think about when i am down .
i keep myself going knowing that i can always eat something .
as i am now !

documents.title: `` mel and sue should get another series , because they are the funniest women on tv . ''
text: beckydavidson asks : is wax a made up name as it 's quite a cool name to just happen ' ?
also , do you think mel and sue will get another series ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:46pm mel and sue should get another series , because they are the funniest women on tv .
and the name came on behalf of ellis island , when they could n't pronounce walcholzocholski .

documents.title: `` i have no role models . and if i did , i 'd probably figure out their flaw. ``
text: brightonian asks : who are your favourite authors ?
and who are the role models ( male or female ) in your life ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:44pm i have no role models .
and probably if i did , i 'd find a loophole , and figure out their flaw .
which is my favourite thing to do .
i suppose abraham lincoln , for reasons that should be obvious .
authors : philip roth , who is as dark as i can find before the works of satan .

documents.title: `` mental health is physical health - it 's your brain , which is just like any other organ ''
text: derekdreery asks : do you believe treatment should be based on condition ( depression , disthymia , ocd , bi-polar , schizo , autistic etc .
etc . )
as in physical health ?
or do you believe that mental health is different and treatment needs to be tailored to the person rather than the illness ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:43pm even physical disease should be tailored to the person .
because no one size fits all .
mental health is physical health - it 's your brain , which is just like any other organ , or part of your body , except it happens to live behind your face .
streetpuppy asks : what exactly is mindfulness and what has it done for you ?

guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:41pm i refer you again to my show or book which in a humorous and articulate way , that took me two years to write , will tell you everything you need to know .
if you do n't want to buy it , borrow it , or steal it from a bookshop .
pieroserra asks : is katherine ryan the young pretender to your throne ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:40pm i ca n't discuss it - she 's way too good-looking .
and so i 'm furious .
rdsk74 writes : i am 6 months into my recovery from diagnosis .
i am half way through your vital and brilliant book .
i have been writing my own blog running with a black dog ' to remove stigma and hopefully help others .
last sunday i violently lapsed into a final scenario predicament .
luckily it failed .
i did n't have a vocabulary / mantra to pull myself back from the breech .
do you have any tricks or words to help me write my own positive ethos , bizarrely am struggling with this simple task of self-help .
please keep doing your work , it really does change lives .
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:36pm make sure you have really close friends , who love you even if you 're depressed .
there is no mantra - you 've got to have friends to pull you out .
if they do n't accept you for having depression , drop them .

documents.title: `` depression is a disease , it is n't a mood . ''
text: mirabaiswingler asks : you very bravely out ' yourself as one of the 1 in 4 in terms of having a mental health problem but how many of the other 3 in 4 do you think also have lived experience , and how can we move towards less of an us and them ' perspective and more that there is a spectrum of human experience ?
is n't this the best way or eradicating stigma ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:34pm sorry to go on about it , but the show i 'm doing now on tour is not about the 1 in 4 so much as the 3 in 4 .
and the fact that we all live in a culture where burnout is the norm .
but let me make it clear : stress and depression are a little like being a little bit pregnant .
you either have depression or you do n't .
it 's a disease , it is n't a mood .
living with pressure and having a real mental disorder are two very different realities - it 's a disease from your genes , or nature/nurture , you do n't develop depression because of stress .
it 's in your dna and your upbringing .
stress does n't help , but it 's not the cause .
v jane windsor asks : can mindfulness practices help with drug and alcohol addiction ?
or any addictions for that matter ?
can we learn to reduce our intake without abstaining ?

guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:31pm mindfulness is only about breaking a habit , whether it 's a habit of thinking you 're a loser , or needing to get through endless lists , or having to get yourself high on your own adrenaline - like i do when i call a taxi to take me to the airport and start packing when it arrives .
drug and alcohol are n't any different - they 're just extensions of the same dopamine rush .
bookworm1968 asks : do you still have that obsessive anxiety like the time with the cushions ?
how have you stopped or do you deal with it differently when it happens ?

guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:30pm in my show and book , i discuss signs that i 'm going downhill , like buying 150 blue and white striped cushions in one sitting that maybe it 's a sign that things are n't going well .
and when i get the cushions , i move onto finding the perfect lampshade , even jumping out of a moving car because i saw one on sale .
yes , i still do that .
but a part of me stands back , and notices how nuts i 'm being .
and just by practising standing back , and not beating myself up about it , i 've got it down to only buying 149 cushions .
id944535 asks : there seems to be very little help going on in london for people with adhd .
i am using mindfulness but is there any other support out there apart from the usual cbt and medication ?
who is the top adhd person in london ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:27pm i do n't know - call mind , or sane , to find out where to get support .

documents.title: `` living a career in sucking the life out of celebrities was n't in the end good for my health , but it was fun ''
text: enterpriseiain asks : for nearly 20 years i ran a set of programmes for people who had dreamt of starting their own business or had an idea and did not know what to do with it .
we organised enterprise conversations .
no business plans , no business speak and no judgement .
our opening question was never what 's your business idea ?
but what brings you here ?

i was delivering these enterprise conversations in banbury a few years ago and you were about to appear a few days later.having seen your programme about depression and just run the sessions it became pretty clear to me that many of the people coming to my enterprise conversations were just about to have some kind of breakdown or were in it or had had one .
the real reason they wanted to start a business was not to make money but to get a way from a life that was rushing them-usually at work .
is this something you have come across before ?
this desire to quit and take control but not knowing how to and then thinking starting your own business is the route out of depression ?

guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:26pm no , i have n't come across it before , but it seems like something they should supply you with at clinics : a way to get out of what is driving you to burnout , and create your own environment .
it 's actually a brilliant idea !
the problem is , starting your own business might actually be the thing that kills you .
but if you can make a living being happy , then you 've hit a bullseye .
living a career in sucking the life out of celebrities was n't in the end good for my health , but it was fun , so that 's why i accidentally fell into this new invention .
misteriks asks : corporations seem happy to squeeze the last drop out of managers in the workplace ; downward pressure to meet targets , upward pressure from unhappy workforces .

concepts like mindfulness are subsequently hijacked as a short-term panacea to help managers feel they can cope by changing themselves , while at the same time showing the company cares ' about the wellbeing of their employees .
i 've seen it all before with stress management , assertiveness , change curves etc .
etc .
what are your thoughts on mindfulness being hollowed out and diluted by cynical corporations and dubious experts ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:23pm if somebody is telling you mindfulness is about changing yourself , then they 're barking up the wrong tree .
whatever they 're offering you is bs , and you should stand up and tell them to not waste their time or money .
if like ariana huffington , or google , your company allows you to cool your engines down or in huffington 's case go and lie down then they really care about you .
if they encourage you to stop when you feel like you 're burning out , and appreciate that it 's stopping that lets you able to work better and live longer , then that 's a good deal .

take a look at mark williams ' book for the real definition of mindfulness - it 's not about relaxing or calming , it 's about knowing when you 're pushing your engine too hard and what to do about it .
so that when you go back to work , you have even more energy , you did n't just veg out .
markh1964 asks : what drove you to re-direct a successful comedy and writing career into one in mindfulness ?
and what aspects of your earlier work prepared you for your current profession ?
in your life today , do you have more or less to make you laugh and/or smile ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:18pm if you want to find out why i rerouted my career , i suggest you come to one of my shows .
you can look up the tour dates in google !
thanks for asking .
i laugh more now .

documents.title: `` tell shrinks what 's in your mind , do n't pretend to be ok. get your money 's worth ! ''
text: heartingilgit writes : help .
i have been on cycle of anti depressants , talk therapy , marriage guidance counselling for almost a year now and am still struggling .
i 've come to the conclusion that i am the only person who can help me , as none of the above has really helped .
therapists have almost washed their hands of me therapy seems to be performance-based .
yyou almost have to act as if you have improved to gain approval , as a patient i can tell what they expect me to say and i leave each session knowing that it has been no help at all .
i want my life back desperately but just do n't have that extra push to grab it .
i was given a new cycle of meds yesterday maybe this time .
i just wanted to know if it is perhaps as case of not having found the right person to talk to yet ?
incidentally i do see starting my own business as the way forward i have so many ideas but no confidence to carry them through .
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:17pm therapy does n't work for everybody .
after a while i started to think : why am i paying ?
the stuff coming out of my mouth is good enough for a one-woman show .
so i started performing my therapy sessions .
i do n't know what you expect a therapist to do .
when you say something like `` you almost have to act as if you have improved to gain approval '' , is something a really good therapist could work with .
if you act like everything 's ok , what are they supposed to do ?
it 's not such a waste when you honestly tell them : this is n't helping .
it 's not self-indulgent .
tell shrinks what 's in your mind , do n't pretend to be ok. get your money 's worth !

documents.title: `` thank you for mentioning my obe . i try to mention it as much as i can ''
text: juliannadenonez writes : i spend a lot of time just trying to be calm , it does n't achieve much more than wasting time .
i practice mindfulness - learnt as a start from your book and show , sane new world , and then working my own variations that help .
recently i have found myself crying , long sobbing gasps that come from deep within .
although they drain me and leave me feeling exhausted , these episodes do seem to actually be a channel for evacuating some of the angst that i have .
do you feel that crying is of any use , or do you think that it is simply making me feel yet more wretched ?
thank you for sharing your story with us , and for striving to extinguish the stigma attached to mental illness .
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:13pm mindfulness is not about trying to be calm .
if you 're not calm , it 's about not faking that you are , but recognising where you are , what state you 're in .

some people ca n't even cry , and are ashamed of being so vulnerable ; the fact that you are talking about it and knowing you 're sobbing and feel the gasps coming from within , that 's very mindful .
that 's what this is : knowing where you are and when you 're there .
thank you for mentioning my obe - i try to mention it as much as i can .
arriet isobel3 asks : hi ruby - what are your key tips about how to maintain mindfulness in busy , hectic london !

guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:10pm i 'm writing a book now that will be out at christmas of exactly what my tips are , and how to stay mindful when shopping , beating the competition , on the treadmill , dealing with your teenagers , and even while you 're burning out so wait for that one .
the working title is wake the fuck up !
robcornelius asks : i was surprised when you said in your last book that exercise is not really a benefit to depression or other mental illness as it is not mindful .
i think you have missed a point there .
a lot of exercise is very mindful indeed .

two examples : a runner is often very mindful of their stride length , cadence and exactly how their foot strikes the ground at every step ; someone lifting any weight has to be very mindful of their posture , exactly how their different muscles are working together to achieve a lift , safety etc .
in both cases its vital to concentrate completely on your body .
there is no space for intrusive thoughts when you are doing a lifting exercise called skullcrushers , you are lying on your back , holding a heavy weight above your face .
for me personally exercise and especially lifting is one of the few times in the day when i can clear my mind by focusing on the weight in my hands .
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:09pm i think you miss my point .
when you 're in the grips of depression and somebody says hey !
you should exercise , that 's like saying to somebody with alzheimer 's to remember where they put their glasses .
and if you tell them to exercise they might get even more depressed .

outside of that though , it 's excellent for your endorphins and if you do n't exercise , you know , good luck for living long as for being mindful , anything you do when you 're focusing on what you 're doing is mindful , i completely agree with you .
ericthepenguin asks : hey ruby , as one of your people - a fellow mental health service user ( other euphemisms available ) - what do you think can or should be done to reduce stigma ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:05pm open your mouth , and make sure other people open their mouths .
just like the gay movement : if everyone kept quiet and in the closet , where would they be now ?
let 's learn from the gay movement .
who knew in our lifetime that would go from such stigma to world supremacy - i mean they 're everywhere !
running countries , in the army , hairdressing , everywhere .
foolbear asks : i loved reading your book , it is just nice to know that you are not alone when you are suffering .
i suffer from anxiety , and find mindfulness does help , but find it really hard to use mindfulness when i am having a bad attack of anxiety , such as in the flow of a panic attack .
do you have any tips for helping me implement these skills when i am in these difficult situations ?
guardian contributor rubywax 06 may 2015 12:04pm i love that you love reading my book !
when you 're in the heart of anxiety or panic , it 's difficult enough - do n't try any therapy !
or listen to any advice if someone tells you to jog , or eat only kelp .
drop it .
ignore them .
when they start to lift , which they will , then you can try a therapy that appeals to you .
to build you a muscle so that you can hear the early warnings of those onslaughts .
medication should not be ignored .

documents.title: ruby is in the building !
text: here 's ruby in the guardian offices , ready to answer your questions ruby wax in the guardian offices may 6 , 2015 beaumont-thomas

documents.title: post your questions for ruby wax
text: comedians are some of the best-equipped people to confront depression , not just by clearing its fug with blasts of wit , but with their constant examination of what makes people happy .
even more adept are those who have battled it themselves , like ruby wax , who has frequently called for a more sympathetic understanding of the black dog .

in her channel 4 show mad confessions she encouraged people to open up about their experiences with mental illness , and outlined her own battle in a ted talk and her standup tour live from the priory .

now in her new show sane new world , based on her book of the same name , she 's applying what she learned in a masters at oxford university about mindfulness : how to consciously adapt your thinking to endure the whirl of information and stress at the heart of modern life .
ahead of a national tour , she 's joining us for a live webchat to answer your questions about it and anything else in her career , at 12 noon on wednesday 6 may .
post your questions in the comments below and she 'll get through as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The comedian and mental health campaigner was here to answer your questions in a live webchat. Read on to find out what she had to say about everything from therapy to mindfulness, her favourite moisturiser and why Mel and Sue are the funniest women on telly.
